      static java.util.Hashtable putNVPairsInTable(org.w3c.dom.Element parent, java.lang.String tagName)
      This method will read all child elements of a parent and read it's child text a series of name/value pairs, for example:
      <Dad key=value key2=value>
      <Kid ckey=cvalue1>thisKey1=this1&thatKey1=that1</Kid>
      <Kid ckey=cvalue2>thisKey2=this2&thatKey2=that2</Kid>
      </Dad>
      Calling putNVPairsInTable( elDad, "Kid" ) will fill the Hashtable with [this1,thatKey1][this2=thatKey2]

      • encodeString

        public static java.lang.String encodeString(java.lang.String val)

      • getParentElementOf

        public static org.w3c.dom.Element getParentElementOf(org.w3c.dom.Node n)
        In parsing XML docs you'll end up iwth Node objects of all kinds, including nested Test stuff, CDATAs, attributes, etc. Where the parent tag? The DOM calls that guy an Element, and this method will return that object given any of those random tags. It'll also give you the parent of an Element.
        Parameters:
        n - the Node object whose parent we want
        Returns:
        an Element of the parent or null if one could not be found

      • findChildElement

        public static org.w3c.dom.Element findChildElement(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                   java.lang.String tagName)
        Returns the first XML Element within the Parent of the given tag name. Once you have the Element of that name, you get get Attributes, child text, and child elements with other methods here.
        For example: 

        
 <Dad key=value key2=value>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue1>Some Text</Kid>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue2>Some More Text</Kid>
        
 </Dad>
        Calling findChildElement( elData, "Kid" ) returns an Element for the first Kid.

      • getChildNodeList

        public static java.util.List getChildNodeList(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                              java.lang.String tag)
        Builds a List from the given criteria (wrapping a NodeList)
        Parameters:
        parent - - the parent Element whose children you want to iterate over
        tag - - the tag Name of the children you want
        Returns:
        a List Object of the immediate child nodes of the given tag, even if there aren't any

      • getChildNodeList

        public static java.util.List getChildNodeList(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                              java.lang.String tag,
                              boolean immediateChildrenOnly)
        Builds a List from the given criteria (wrapping a NodeList)
        Parameters:
        parent - - the parent Element whose children you want to iterate over
        tag - - the tag Name of the children you want
        immediateChildrenOnly - - if you only want direct children, not grandchildren/etc, say yes here
        Returns:
        a List Object of the immediate child nodes of the given tag, even if there aren't any

      • getChildNodeList

        public static java.util.List getChildNodeList(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                              boolean immediateChildrenOnly)
        Builds a List from the given criteria (wrapping a NodeList)
        Parameters:
        parent - - the parent Element whose children you want to iterate over
        immediateChildrenOnly - - if you only want direct children, not grandchildren/etc, say yes here
        Returns:
        a List Object of the immediate child nodes of the given tag, even if there aren't any

      • childEnumerator

        Builds an Enumeration of the given children

      • getChildText

        public static java.lang.String getChildText(org.w3c.dom.Element parent)
        Finds he child text of a given Element.
        When you have a non-attribute value, like the following:

        
 <Dad key=value key2=value>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue1>Some Text</Kid>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue2>Some More Text</Kid>
        
 </Dad>
        If you call getChildText( elKid1 ) you'll get "Some Text" It supports standard child text and CDATA sections.

      • streamMap

        public static void streamMap(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
             java.util.Map map)
        This method writes the given map (these should be Strings but if they are not we'll write the toString() of them). The model is like this
        <MapKey1>MapValue-BASE64Encoded</MapKey1>
        <MapKey2>MapValue-BASE64Encoded</MapKey2>
        Parameters:
        ps -
        map -

      • readObject

        public static java.lang.Object readObject(org.w3c.dom.Element parent)
                                   throws java.io.IOException,
                                          java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        This is the companion to the streamMap method above. It will build a map of every child tag to the given tag, taking the tagname as the map key and the child text as the map entry. It assumes the child textis base64 encoded
        Parameters:
        parent -
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException

      • getOcurranceCountFromParent

        public static int getOcurranceCountFromParent(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                              org.w3c.dom.Element tag)
        This method will count how many tags of the same name are "above" the tag you give from the top of the parent's tree. So if it's the first one, you'll get a 0 back. Note that this does a deep search, so all tags of the given name, even those that are nephews and great newphews, are counted.
        Parameters:
        parent - - the parent element to search from. Send Document.getDocumentElement() for the very top
        tag - - the Element you want to calculate on
        Returns:
        the 0-based offset from the parent of this tag, or -1 if there was an error

      • getAttributeOrChildText

        public static java.lang.String getAttributeOrChildText(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                       java.lang.String attribTag)
        For legacy support, some docs may have an attribute name=value and newer ones have value in them. This method tries the attribute first...
        Parameters:
        parent -
        attribTag -
        Returns:

      • getChildFirstCDATAText

        public static java.lang.String getChildFirstCDATAText(org.w3c.dom.Element parent)
        Finds the first child CData text of a given Element.

      • findChildGetItsText

        public static java.lang.String findChildGetItsText(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                   java.lang.String tag)
        Finds the first child element of the given parent and returns the text element as a String. For example:

        
 <Dad key=value key2=value>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue1>Some Text</Kid>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue2>Some More Text</Kid>
        
 </Dad>
        Calling findChildGetItsText( elDad, "Kid" ) returns "Some Text"

      • findChildGetItsFirstCDATAText

        public static java.lang.String findChildGetItsFirstCDATAText(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                             java.lang.String tag)
        Finds the first child element of the given parent and returns the first CDATA element as a string or null if none there.

      • putElementsInTable

        public static java.util.Hashtable putElementsInTable(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                     java.lang.String tagName,
                                     java.lang.String keyKey,
                                     java.lang.String valueKey)
        example is to get all the properties from the Registry... 

        
 <Dad key=value key2=value>
        
         <Kid ckey=ckey1 cValue=v1>Some Text</Kid>
        
         <Kid ckey=ckey2 cValue=v2>Some More Text</Kid>
        
 </Dad>
        Calling like putElementsInTable( elDad, "Kid", "cKey", "cValue" ) will fill the Hashtable with [ckey1,v1][ckey2,v2]

      • putNVPairsInTable

        public static java.util.Hashtable putNVPairsInTable(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                    java.lang.String tagName)
        This method will read all child elements of a parent and read it's child text a series of name/value pairs, for example: 

        
 <Dad key=value key2=value>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue1>thisKey1=this1&thatKey1=that1</Kid>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue2>thisKey2=this2&thatKey2=that2</Kid>
        
 </Dad>
        Calling putNVPairsInTable( elDad, "Kid" ) will fill the Hashtable with [this1,thatKey1][this2=thatKey2]

      • stringToProperties

        public static java.util.Hashtable stringToProperties(java.lang.String sProperties)
        public static Hashtable stringToProperties(String sProperties)

        This method knows how to parse a string of key=value[&etc] tokens into a property table.

        Parameters:
        sProperties - - the string to be parsed, for example thisKey1=this1&thatKey1

        Returns:
        Hashtable of the key/value pairs.

      • readAllSubElementText

        public static java.util.Vector readAllSubElementText(org.w3c.dom.Element parent,
                                     java.lang.String tagName)
        Gets all the text elements that are children of a given node. For example, 

        
 <Dad key=value key2=value>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue1>Some Text</Kid>
        
         <Kid ckey=cvalue2>Some More Text</Kid>
        
 </Dad>
        Calling readAllSubElementText( elDad, "Kid" ) will return a Vector of the Strings [Some Text,Some More Text]

      • getBooleanAttribute

        public static boolean getBooleanAttribute(org.w3c.dom.Element e,
                          java.lang.String attr,
                          boolean def)
        This method is a handy way to evaluate the value of an attribute as a boolean value. The rules for what Strings constitute booleans is taken directly from the Boolean object.

      • readChildStrings

        public static java.util.List readChildStrings(org.w3c.dom.Element comp,
                              java.lang.String wrapTag)
        This is a quick way to read a set of simple child tags from a parent. Consider the following: 
         <Dad>
        
   <Child>SomeInfo</Child>
        
   <Child>SomeMoreInfo</Child>
        
 </Dad>
        You'll get back a List of String objects that have SomeInfo and SimMoreInfo if you call this method with the Element object of Dad and the wrapTag of Child
        Parameters:
        comp -
        wrapTag -
        Returns:
        a List of String objects

      • streamXMLHeader

        public static void streamXMLHeader(java.io.PrintWriter ps)

      • streamListOfStrings

        public static void streamListOfStrings(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                       java.util.List list,
                       java.lang.String wrapTag)
        This method is the complement of readChildStrings b/c this method will write a List of Strings (or anything else that has a suitable toString()) and write the children. It assumes you've already streamed the parent tag, so we will stream a child tag named wrapTag for each list entry
        Parameters:
        ps -
        list -
        wrapTag -

      • streamOpenTag

        public static void streamOpenTag(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                 java.lang.String tagName)
        This is a convenience method for writing an open tag.
        Parameters:
        ps - stream you want the tag pushed into
        tagName - the name of the tag, w/o any angle brackets!

      • streamOpenTag

        public static void streamOpenTag(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                 java.lang.String tagName,
                 java.util.Map attribs)
        This is a convenience method for writing an open tag that has attributes that will be handled easily for you. The quotes are added to the value side of every attribute, and encoding is performed.
        Parameters:
        ps - stream you want the tag pushed into
        tagName - the name of the tag, w/o any angle brackets!
        attribs -

      • streamOpenAndCloseTag

        public static void streamOpenAndCloseTag(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                         java.lang.String tagName,
                         java.util.Map attribs)
        This is a convenience method for writing an open tag that has attributes that will be handled easily for you. The quotes are added to the value side of every attribute, and encoding is performed.
        Parameters:
        ps - stream you want the tag pushed into
        tagName - the name of the tag, w/o any angle brackets!
        attribs -

      • streamOpenTag

        public static void streamOpenTag(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                 java.lang.String tagName,
                 java.lang.String attribs)
        This is a convenience method for writing an open tag.
        Parameters:
        ps - stream you want the tag pushed into
        tagName - the name of the tag, w/o any angle brackets!
        attribs - if not null, this presumed to be valid XML to put after the tag name and before the tag close. this should be an attribut list, empty String, or null. The attribute list must look like "name=value name2=value" and use quotes for value XML...

      • streamCloseTag

        public static void streamCloseTag(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                  java.lang.String tagName)
        Complement to the streamOpenTag to close a tag you've already opened.
        Parameters:
        ps -
        tagName -
